Journal of Clinical Nursing https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ ABSTRACT Aims To examine the effectiveness of acupressure on sleep quality in cancer patients and to identify the population‐level and intervention‐level characteristics associated with the intervention outcome of sleep quality. Design Systematic review and meta‐analysis. Data Sources PubMed, EMBASE, APA PsycInfo, Web of Science, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure and WanFang were searched for eligible randomised controlled trials from inception to April 2024. Methods Methodological quality was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for Randomised Trials 2.0. A random‐effects model was used for the meta‐analysis. Subgroup analyses and the meta‐regression aimed to investigate potential heterogeneity and identify characteristics that may be associated with more favourable acupressure outcomes. Results In total, 22 randomised controlled trials involving 2113 participants were included in this meta‐analysis. Compared with various control groups, acupressure exhibited a significant beneficial effect on sleep quality in cancer patients at post‐intervention (SMD = −1.38, 95% CI [−1.81, −0.95], p p p p Conclusions Acupressure appears to be a promising intervention for enhancing sleep quality among cancer patients. Future studies should elucidate the long‐term effects of acupressure on sleep quality, identify effective acupressure characteristics and determine which types of cancer patients benefit from this intervention. Impact This study provides a comprehensive summary of evidence supporting the use of acupressure to enhance sleep quality in cancer patients and demonstrates its effectiveness in clinical nursing practice. Reporting Method PRISMA 2020 statement. Summary  What does this paper contribute to the wider global clinical community? ○ Acupressure can effectively improve sleep quality, and the effects can persist to a 4‐week follow‐up in cancer patients. ○ Auricular and somatic acupressure provided by healthcare professionals (including nurses) and self‐administered acupressure with different stimulation materials showed benefits for sleep quality in patients with various cancer types who underwent surgery, non‐surgery, or a combination of both, during treatment or post‐treatment survival. 1 Introduction Cancer poses a significant challenge to public health worldwide (Mao et al. 2022 2024 2022 2023 2022 2022 2020 2013 2021 2019 2021 2021 Poor sleep quality affects approximately 57.4% of cancer patients, and this prevalence is approximately two to three times higher than in the general population (Chen et al. 2024 2023 2020 2024 2020 2024 2020 2024 2023 2017 Pharmacological interventions such as benzodiazepines and antihistamines are commonly used to treat poor sleep quality in adults (Sateia et al. 2017 2015 2022 2018 2018 2024 2018 2024 2022 2021 2021 2022 2022 2024 qi 2022 qi 2021 qi 2018 2023 2022 2006 However, randomised controlled trials (RCTs) on the effectiveness of acupressure on sleep quality in cancer patients have yielded inconclusive findings. Some RCTs have demonstrated the benefits of acupressure (Li et al. 2023 2021 2023 2022 2023 2014 2022 2021 2 Methods 2.1 Protocol Registration The systematic review and meta‐analysis were preregistered under PROSPERO following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta‐analyses (PRISMA) guidelines (Page et al. 2021 S1 2.2 Search Strategies A comprehensive literature search was conducted independently by two reviewers using the following databases: PubMed, Embase, APA PsycINFO, Web of Science, CINAHL Plus, Cochrane Library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) and Wan Fang. The search included results from the inception of the databases to 8 April 2024. The reference lists of relevant systematic reviews and grey literature were also checked for additional potentially eligible studies. The literature search process involved using combinations of keywords from the following categories: acupressure, sleep and cancer. The details of the search strategy can be found in Supplementary file S2 2.3 Eligibility Criteria The inclusion criteria were as follows. (1) Population: Adults aged 18 years or older, diagnosed with cancer, with no restriction on gender, cancer type, or treatment. (2) Intervention: Studies that assessed the effectiveness of acupressure, including auricular acupressure and somatic acupressure. (3) Comparison: Studies incorporating a control group that received either usual care, patient education, no intervention, or a placebo. (4) Outcomes: Studies that evaluated sleep quality as the primary outcome using any empirically validated scale. Secondary outcomes included sleep parameters such as total sleep time (TST), onset latency (OL), sleep efficiency (SE) and wake after sleep onset (WASO), assessed by actigraphy, Actiwatch or sleep diary. (5) Study design: RCTs. (6) Language: Studies published in either English or Chinese. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) the full text was not available, (2) the study included participants with psychiatric diseases, (3) the participants were taking medication for sleep problems and (4) the mean difference (standard deviation) from baseline to post‐intervention or follow‐up could not be calculated. 2.4 Study Selection and Data Extraction The retrieved studies were imported into EndNote 21 (Gotschall 2023 2.5 Quality Assessment of Included Studies The Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for Randomized Trials 2.0 (RoB‐2) was used to assess the methodological quality of the eligible studies (Sterne et al. 2019 2.6 Data Synthesis and Statistical Analysis The meta‐analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.4 (RevMan 2020 2012 2023 2007 p 2023 I 2 I 2 2003 p 2023 2002 2023 The subgroup analyses were conducted based on categorical characteristics: cancer type, cancer treatment type, treatment phase, acupressure type and acupressure provider. Univariate meta‐regression was performed on the continuous characteristics: sample size, number of acupoints, number of acupressure sessions, duration of each session, and duration of the acupressure intervention. Subgroup analyses and meta‐regression were conducted to explore the potential source of heterogeneity and the potential characteristics associated with improved sleep quality. These characteristics were identified from previous research (Waits et al. 2018 2021 2023 3 Results 3.1 Search Results Figure 1 FIGURE 1 PRISMA flow diagram. The pooled result for the included studies revealed that acupressure had a large effect on improved sleep quality (SMD = −1.38, 95% CI [−1.81, −0.95], p I 2 3 p I 2 4 FIGURE 3 Forest plot of effect sizes for comparisons between acupressure and control conditions on sleep quality at post‐intervention. [Colour figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com FIGURE 4 Forest plot of effect sizes for comparisons between acupressure and control conditions on sleep quality at 4‐week follow‐up. [Colour figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com 3.3.2 Sleep Parameters Acupressure had significant effects on the secondary outcomes, with a large effect size favouring acupressure for SE (SMD = 0.77, 95% CI [0.27, 1.26], p I 2 n S5 p I 2 n S6 2022 2021 2022 2022 p I 2 n 2021 2022 2022 S7 3.3.3 Subgroup Analysis 3.3.3.1 Cancer Type A subgroup analysis was performed to explore whether the type of cancer influenced the observed effects. The acupressure intervention showed a statistically significant improvement in sleep quality among patients with breast cancer (SMD = −1.05, 95% CI [−1.51, −0.58], p I 2 p I 2 p p S8 3.3.3.2 Cancer Treatment Type A subgroup analysis was conducted to examine whether the type of cancer treatment influenced the effect size. No statistically significant subgroup difference was found ( p p I 2 p I 2 p I 2 S9 3.3.3.3 Treatment Phase A subgroup analysis was conducted to determine whether treatment phases affected the observed effects. The acupressure intervention demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in sleep quality both during treatment (SMD = −0.98, 95% CI [−1.31, −0.65], p I 2 p I 2 p S10 3.3.3.4 Provider of the Acupressure Intervention A subgroup analysis was performed to indicate whether the effect size of the intervention differed according to the acupressure provider. No statistically significant subgroup difference was found ( p p I 2 p I 2 S11 3.3.3.5 Acupressure Type A subgroup analysis was conducted to assess whether the type of acupressure intervention influenced the size of the effects. Both auricular acupressure (SMD = −1.75, 95% CI [−2.50, −0.99], p I 2 p I 2 p S12 3.3.3.6 Stimulation Materials Used for Acupressure A subgroup analysis was used to examine whether the stimulation materials used for acupressure influenced the effect size. No statistically significant subgroup differences were detected ( p p I 2 p I 2 p I 2 S13 3.3.3.7 Control Condition A subgroup analysis was undertaken to determine whether the type of control condition influenced the observed effects. Acupressure produced a statistically significant improvement in sleep quality compared with usual care (SMD = −1.31, 95% CI [−1.82, −0.80], p I 2 p I 2 p I 2 p S14 3.3.4 Meta‐Regression The results of the meta‐regression are presented in Supplementary file S15 p p p p p 3.3.5 Sensitivity Analysis The leave‐one‐out analyses revealed that the outcomes for sleep quality remained robust at post‐intervention (Supplementary file S16 S17 S18 S19 p I 2 S20 2022 p I 2 2022 p I 2 3.3.6 Publication Bias Asymmetry was observed in the funnel plot (Figure 5 p S21 p FIGURE 5 Funnel plot to evaluate publication bias in studies used for meta‐analysis of sleep quality at post‐intervention. 4 Discussion This study is the first to provide a comprehensive, synthesised evaluation of the effectiveness of acupressure for improving sleep quality across various cancer conditions and to explore the potential population‐level and intervention‐level characteristics associated with better intervention outcomes. The findings revealed that acupressure significantly improved sleep quality in overall cancer patients at post‐intervention (SMD = −1.38) and 4‐week follow‐up (SMD = −0.33) compared with various control groups. The adjusted results for publication bias indicated that it did not impact these findings. This result aligns with the meta‐analysis by Lu et al. ( 2022 2021 2019 2009 2008 2008 2003 2018 Regarding sleep measures, acupressure demonstrated significant improvements in SE (SMD = 0.77) and TST (SMD = 0.68), but not in WASO (SMD = −0.54). However, caution is warranted when interpreting the findings regarding TST and WASO due to the instability observed in the sensitivity analyses. The sensitivity analysis results for TST suggested that the heterogeneity potentially stemmed from the studies by Liu, Wang et al. ( 2022 2022 2021 2021 2017 2021 2016 2022 2016 2023 2021 2021 2022 This study also investigated the population‐level and intervention‐level characteristics that influenced the effectiveness of acupressure on sleep quality among cancer patients through subgroup analyses and meta‐regressions. First, it was found that acupressure had a large effect on patients with ovarian cancer (SMD = −3.11), breast cancer (SMD = −1.05), and lung cancer (SMD = −0.94). This implies that acupressure could be an effective intervention for a broad range of cancer patients. A previous meta‐analysis reported a similar finding of a large positive effect of acupressure on sleep quality in patients with lung cancer (SMD = 0.80) (Lu et al. 2022 2018 Second, the subgroup analysis revealed that acupressure significantly improved sleep quality across all treatment types: surgical treatments (SMD = −1.07), non‐surgical treatments (SMD = −1.28), and combined surgical and non‐surgical treatments (SMD = −0.93). This finding indicates the potential of acupressure to enhance sleep quality at any stage and with any type of cancer treatment. However, due to the lack of detailed information regarding the cancer treatments administered in the reported studies, the specific effects of acupressure on sleep quality among cancer patients undergoing specific non‐surgical treatments (e.g., chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormone therapy) remain uncertain (Miller et al. 2022 Third, the subgroup analysis found that acupressure had a large effect on sleep quality in cancer patients, whether they were undergoing treatment (SMD = −0.98) or were in post‐treatment survival (SMD = −0.96). The consistent effectiveness may be attributed to acupressure's ability to modulate the autonomic nervous system, promote relaxation, and potentially influence neurotransmitter levels (such as serotonin and melatonin), which collectively contribute to improved sleep regulation regardless of the treatment phase (Hmwe et al. 2019 2013 Fourth, the findings demonstrated that acupressure, whether delivered by healthcare professionals (SMD = −1.25) or self‐administered (SMD = −1.44), had a large effect on improved sleep quality. In clinical settings, the acupressure intervention protocol (e.g., identifying appropriate acupoints, sequencing and timing of acupressure application per acupoint, and the use of specific acupressure techniques) can be easily taught and is accepted by both nurses and patients (Harris 1997 2018 2020 2020 2022 Fifth, the subgroup analysis revealed that auricular acupressure (SMD = −1.75) and somatic acupressure (SMD = −1.11) significantly improved sleep quality, supporting previous systematic reviews on the benefits of these methods in cancer patients (Liu et al. 2020 2022 2021 2014 2015 qi qi 2016 2012 2015 2009 2021 2022 2002 2019 2016 2018 2010 2023 2014 2001 Sixth, the subgroup analysis found that the use of the hand (SMD = −1.11), semen vaccariae (SMD = −1.81) and magnetic beads (SMD = −1.04) significantly improved sleep quality in cancer patients. However, as there have been reported cases of allergies associated with the use of semen vaccariae (Sha et al. 2016 Seventh, the meta‐regression analysis did not identify any specific characteristics that could enhance the outcome of the intervention. Regarding the number of acupoints used, the majority of studies used between three and six acupoints, which is consistent with findings from previous meta‐analyses (Waits et al. 2018 2020 2023 In addition, significant heterogeneity was observed in the sleep outcomes, with I 2 2022 4.1 Limitations This meta‐analysis also has several limitations. First, the majority of the studies were conducted in China, and only studies published in English or Chinese were included. This may restrict the generalisability of the findings to other countries or regions. Second, the analysis was limited to examining the effectiveness of acupressure on sleep quality specifically in patients with breast or lung cancer because of a lack of sufficient data on other cancer types. This limitation may limit the generalisability of the results to patients with different types of cancer. Third, only three studies included a 4‐week follow‐up assessment, which constrained our ability to evaluate the long‐term effects of acupressure on poor sleep quality. Fourth, the lack of comprehensive details about the acupressure intervention protocol (e.g., specific acupressure techniques used, and the background of the healthcare professionals) in the included RCTs prevented a detailed exploration of the effective acupressure protocol for improving sleep quality. Fifth, there was considerable heterogeneity across the studies. Although a series of subgroup analyses and a meta‐regression were performed to explore the heterogeneity, the underlying sources remain unidentified. Lastly, the presence of a publication bias suggests that the results should be interpreted with caution. 5 Conclusion This meta‐analysis indicates that acupressure could be a more effective intervention for enhancing sleep quality in cancer patients than sham acupressure, patient education, usual care and no intervention. Nonetheless, there is a need for future high‐quality RCTs with longer follow‐up periods and detailed acupressure protocols across diverse geographical settings to further explore the effectiveness of acupressure on sleep quality among cancer patients.
